Fig 5 NiMo/NiCo2O4 as synergy catalyst supported on nickel foam for efficient overall water splitting Huaping Chen Investigation Visualization Writing – original draft a Shizhang Qiao Supervision b Jing Yang Supervision Funding acquisition Writing – review & editing a ⁎ Xiwen Du Supervision a a Institute of New-Energy Materials, Key Laboratory of Advanced Ceramics and Machining Technology of Ministry of Education, School of Materials Science and Engineering, Tianjin University, Tianjin 300072, China Institute of New-Energy Materials Key Laboratory of Advanced Ceramics and Machining Technology of Ministry of Education School of Materials Science and Engineering Tianjin University Tianjin 300072 China aInstitute of New-Energy Materials, Key Laboratory of Advanced Ceramics and Machining Technology of Ministry of Education, School of Materials Science and Engineering, Tianjin University, Tianjin 300072, China b Centre for Materials in Energy and Catalysis (CMEC), School of Chemical Engineering and Advanced Materials, The University of Adelaide, SA 5005, Australia Centre for Materials in Energy and Catalysis (CMEC) School of Chemical Engineering and Advanced Materials The University of Adelaide SA 5005 Australia bCentre for Materials in Energy and Catalysis (CMEC), School of Chemical Engineering and Advanced Materials, The University of Adelaide, SA 5005, Australia ⁎ Corresponding author at: Materials Science and Engineering, Tianjin University, No. 92, Weijin Road, NanKai Disctri…, Tianjin, None Selected 300072, China. Materials Science and Engineering Tianjin University No. 92, Weijin Road, NanKai Disctri… Tianjin 300072 China It is highly desirable to develop efficient and low-cost bifunctional HER/OER electrocatalysts for overall water splitting. Herein, Ni5Mo/NiCo2O4 heterojunctions loaded on nickel foam were prepared. The catalyst shows excellent bifunctional activity, with an HER overpotential of 44 mV at 10 mA cm−2 and an OER overpotential of 305 mV at 50 mA cm−2 in alkaline electrolyte. In addition, it is worth noting that the overpotential of HER and OER at 500 mA cm−2 are only 229 mV and 368 mV, respectively. It is evidenced that the combination of Ni5Mo and NiCo2O4 transfers electrons from Co2+/Co3+ to Ni0/Mo0, which optimizes the electronic structures of the active sites of Ni0, Mo0 and Co3+, thus greatly enhances the intrinsic HER and OER activities. When Ni5Mo/NiCo2O4/NF is used as anode and cathode for water splitting under alkaline conditions, a stable current density of 10 mA cm−2 can be achieved at a low cell voltage of 1.54 V and a long-term stability up to 50 h. This work highlights the synergy effect of alloy and oxide heterojunctions in efficient water electrocatalysis. Graphical abstract Due to the optimization of electronic structure of interface metal active sites for reaction intermediates absorption via favorable electronic coupling at the hybrid interface, the overall water splitting activity of NiMo/NiCo2O4 heterojunction was significantly improved. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Synergistic effect NiMo/NiCo2O4 heterojunction Hydrogen evolution reaction Oxygen evolution reaction Overall water splitting 1 Introduction With increasingly serious environmental pollution and energy crisis, developing renewable energy source has become imminent [1–6]. Hydrogen energy is considered as one of the ideal energy sources in the future because of its high energy density and environmental friendliness [7–10]. As a clean and attractive approach to produce hydrogen (H2) in industry, electrochemical water splitting consists of two half reactions, namely hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) [11–16]. However, large-scale application of the most active catalysts for HER (e.g., Pt) and OER (e.g., IrO2 or RuO2) is limited in industry due to their high cost and low natural abundance [17–19]. Meanwhile, the working medium for HER catalysts is usually incompatible with that for OER catalysts, therefore, it is difficult to pair the two electrodes in the integrated electrolytic cell for practical application. In addition, from the perspective of productivity and cost-effectiveness, the use of different catalysts for HER and OER electrodes might lead to inconvenience in catalyst preparation and cell assembly [20,21]. For the above reasons, a great deal of work has been done to manufacture bifunctional electrocatalysts that are effective for both HER and OER in the same water-based alkaline or acidic media [22–27]. Among various non-precious metal catalysts, NiMo alloys are considered to be promising HER electrocatalysts in alkaline electrolytes due to their moderate hydrogen binding energy [28–31]. In recent years, studies on NiMo alloys catalysts have been focused on morphology regulation [32,33] and heteroatom doping [34]. However, the inferior OER activity of NiMo alloy electrocatalysts, owning to week absorption of oxygen-containing intermediates, has limited their application as bifunctional HER/OER electrocatalysts for overall water splitting. Note that, metal oxides have been regarded as good OER catalysts, and a number of studies have shown that metal/metal oxides hybrid materials are prospective bifunctional HER and OER electrocatalysts [35,36]. Nevertheless, it should be pointed out that only when the electronic structures of interface metal active sites are optimized for reaction intermediates absorption via favorable electronic coupling at the hybrid interface, could the HER and OER intrinsic activities be significantly improved [37,38]. In other words, effective interface engineering is highly important for rational design of efficient synergistic catalysts for overall water splitting. Up to now, for the NiMo alloy-based catalysts, it is still challenging to construct appropriate interface to realize robust HER and OER activity improvement. In addition, an in-situ growth of catalysts on porous current collector (e.g., nickel foam) is preferable for preparing self-supporting electrodes with good durability, large exposed active area, and rapid charge transfer. More importantly, the macroporous structure would greatly facilitate rapid electrolyte penetration and fast H2/O2 gas bubble release in the process of water electrolysis, which would be particularly critical for industrial water splitting at larger current densities [39–42]. In this study, NiMo/NiCo2O4 hybrid catalysts in-situ grown on nickel foam was prepared by hydrothermal-annealing-electrodeposition method for the first time. The strong electron interaction between NiMo alloy and NiCo2O4 nanoparticles lead to remarkable enhancement of HER and OER activities, with HER overpotential as low as 44 mV at 10 mA cm−2 and OER overpotential of only 305 mV at 50 mA cm−2 in basic electrolyte. Besides, it also demonstrates very low overpotential at a large current density (500 mA cm−2). More importantly, when used as the cathode and anode catalysts for overall water splitting, NiMo/NiCo2O4 enables a stable current density of 10 mA cm−2 at a low voltage of 1.54 V. Meanwhile, it also affords an excellent stability for water electrolysis. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Nickel chloride hexahydrate [NiCl2•6H2O] was purchased from Tianjin Damao Chemical Reagent Factory. Cobalt chloride hexahydrate [CoCl2•6H2O] was purchased from Tianjin Heans Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd. Nickel sulfate hexahydrate [NiSO4•6H2O] and sodium molybdate dihydrate [Na2MoO4•2H2O] were purchased from Tianjin FengChuan Chemical Reagent Technology Co., Ltd. Urea [CH4N2O] and trisodium citrate [C6H5O7Na3•2H2O] were purchased from Tianjin Yuanli Chemical Co., Ltd. Ammonia was purchased from Tianjin ComeO Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. Nafion solution (5 wt%), KOH (99.98%), commercial Pt/C (20 wt%) were supplied by Tianjin Incole Union Technology Co., Ltd. All the chemicals were analytical grade and used without further purification in the experiments. Nickel foam (NF, thickness: 2.0 mm) purchased from Cyber Electrochemical Materials Network is used as the growth substrate. The nickel foam was first cleaned in distilled water for 10 min, followed by ultrasonic cleaning in 3 M HCl for 30 min, and finally ultrasonic cleaning in ethanol and distilled water for 10 min. The cleaned nickel foam was placed in a vacuum drying oven to dry at 60 °C for 6 h for later use. 2.2 Preparation of NiCo2O4/NF Nickel chloride hexahydrate (2.5 mmol), cobalt chloride hexahydrate (5.0 mmol), and urea (9.0 mmol) were dissolved in 30 mL deionized water by sonication. Then the aqueous solution and the cleaned nickel foam were transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless autoclave (50 mL volume) and maintained at 120 °C for 8 h. After being washed with deionized water and dried at 60 °C for 6 h in a vacuum drying oven, followed by calcination at 300 °C for 3 h, the final NiCo2O4/NF was obtained (loading ∼2 mg). 2.3 Preparation of Ni5Mo/NiCo2O4/NF and Ni5Mo/NF NiCo2O4/NF (deposition area 1 × 1 cm2), saturated calomel electrode (SCE) and platinum plate were used as working electrode, reference electrode and counter electrode respectively. Nickel sulfate hexahydrate (3.75 mmol), sodium molybdate dihydrate (2.75 mmol), and trisodium citrate (4.30 mmol) were dissolved in 50 mL deionized water by sonication. Adjust the pH of electrolyte to 9 with ammonia. Electrodeposition was carried out at 180 mA cm−2 for 30 min at 38 °C . After cleaning with deionized water and drying in 60 °C vacuum oven for 6 h, the final Ni5Mo/NiCo2O4/NF (loading ∼3.0 mg) was obtained. For comparison, Ni5Mo/NF (loading ∼1.0 mg) was prepared under the same electrodeposition conditions using only NF. 2.4 Preparation of Ni5Mo+NiCo2O4/NF The NiCo2O4 on NiCo2O4/NF was scraped off and ground into powder. 4.0 mg NiCo2O4 powder was dispersed in 200 μL water, 200 μL ethanol and 50 μL Nafion, and the solution was ultrasonicated for 1 h to make the solution black uniform ink. The Ni5Mo+NiCo2O4/NF electrode was prepared by dropping 225 μL ink onto Ni5Mo/NF (0.5 × 0.5 cm2) to dry. 2.5 Preparation of Pt/C/NF and RuO2/NF 6.0 mg Pt/C powder or 6.0 mg RuO2 powder was dispersed in 200 μL water, 200 μL ethanol and 50 μL Nafion, and the solution was ultrasonicated for 1 h to make the solution black uniform ink. The Pt/C/NF or RuO2/NF electrode was prepared by dropping 225 μL ink onto Ni5Mo/NF (0.5 × 0.5 cm2) to dry. 2.6 Materials characterization The XRD patterns of the samples were characterized by D8 Advance X-ray Diffractometer with Cu-Kα as Radiation Source. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM), high-resolution TEM (HR-TEM), energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS), EDS mapping, and selected area electron diffraction (SAED) were acquired on a TEM-2100f with an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images were conducted on a Hitachi s4800 scanning electron microscope. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was collected by PHI Quantum 2000 scanning ESCA microprobe spectrometer to analyze the valence states and electron transfer of the samples. The binding energy of XPS spectra was calibrated relative to the C 1 s peak (284.8 eV). 2.7 Electrochemical tests The electrocatalytic activities of all samples were measured on CHI660E electrochemical analyzer in a three-electrode configuration at room temperature. The electrolyte solution was 1.0 M KOH. Ni5Mo/NiCo2O4/NF, NiCo2O4/NF, Ni5Mo/NF, Ni5Mo+NiCo2O4/NF, Pt/C/NF, RuO2/NF were used as working electrode (0.5 × 0.5 cm2), carbon rod and saturated calomel electrode (SCE) were used as counter electrode and reference electrode respectively. All applied potentials were converted with respect to reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE), E RHE = E SCE + 0.0592 pH + 0.242 V. Before data acquisition, cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves were repeatedly recorded at scanning rate of 50 mV s − 1, until the signals were stabilized. Then linear sweep voltammograms (LSV) curves were measured at a scan rate of 1 mV s − 1 and all data were iR-corrected according to the formula E corrected = E measured -iR s (R s is the solution resistance obtained from the EIS test). The Tafel slope is obtained by fitting the linear part of the Tafel curve to the Tafel equation η=blog(j)+a. The electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was carried out with frequencies ranging from 0.1 Hz to 106 Hz under −0.13 V (vs. RHE, HER) and 1.6 V (vs. RHE, OER). The electrochemical active surface area (ECSA) of the material was estimated by calculating the double layer capacitance. CV measurements were performed at different scan rates of 20, 40, 60, 80, and 100 mV s − 1. The ECSA could be calculated based on (1) E C S A = S geo X C dl C s where C s is the specific electrochemical double layer capacitance, and its value in alkaline medium is 0.040 mF cm−2, and S geo represents the geometric surface area of the working electrode [43]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst structural and morphological characterization The XRD patterns of the Ni5Mo/NiCo2O4/NF, NiCo2O4/NF, Ni5Mo /NF, NF is depicted in Fig. 1 (a), (b) and Fig. S1. The diffraction peaks at 44.51°, 51.85° and 76.37° correspond to the (111), (200), and (220) planes of Ni (PDF #04–0850). Meanwhile, the diffraction peaks at 2θ values of 31.15°, 36.70°, 59.09° and 64.98° can be attributed to the (220), (311), (511) and (440) planes of NiCo2O4 (PDF #20–0781), which indicates the successful synthesis of NiCo2O4/NF. When the Ni5Mo alloy was electrodeposited on NF and NiCo2O4/NF, no peak of Ni5Mo was observed. This is because the peak of NF substrate is so strong that the peak of NiMo alloy is concealed. In order to eliminate the influence of the NF substrate, the sample was scraped off the nickel foam for XRD characterization. The diffraction peak at 43.92° corresponds to the characteristic peak of Ni5Mo. Compared with the peak of Ni, the peak of Ni5Mo is shifted to a lower angle, this is due to the successful incorporation of Mo atoms into the lattice of Ni in NiMo alloy, resulting in lattice expansion of Ni. As shown in Fig. S2, the uniform distribution of Ni and Mo in the Ni5Mo/NF sample further indicates that the successful synthesis of the NiMo alloy, and the atomic ratio of Ni to Mo is 5:1 (as shown in Table S1). The dominant diffraction peaks of Ni5Mo/NiCo2O4 (Fig. 1a) are completely consistent with the crystal phases of NiCo2O4 and Ni5Mo, which indicates that Ni5Mo/NiCo2O4/NF has been successfully synthesized. The morphology and structure of the samples were analyzed by SEM and TEM. The electrodeposited Ni5Mo on nickel foam showed cauliflower structures of different sizes (Fig. S3). As shown in Fig. S4, the NiCo2O4 growing on nickel foam showed short rod structure of nanoparticle accumulation, the diameter of the short rod was about 100 nm and the diameter of the prepared NiCo2O4 nanoparticle was about 30 nm. After electrodeposition of Ni5Mo on NiCo2O4/NF, NiCo2O4 and Ni5Mo nanoparticles accumulate together, the surface of the nanoparticles become smoother and the nanoparticles are uniformly loaded on the nickel foam (Fig. 1c). Furthermore, the TEM images also confirm the accumulation of NiCo2O4 and Ni5Mo nanoparticles (Fig. 1d). Moreover, the HRTEM image of the Ni5Mo/NiCo2O4/NF (Fig. 1e) distinctly shows two sets of lattice fringes. The measured lattice fringe spacings are 0.208 nm and 0.245 nm, which match with the (111) crystal plane of the Ni5Mo and the (311) crystal plane of NiCo2O4, respectively. The corresponding selected area electron diffraction (SAED) of the region shown in Fig. 1(d) (Fig. 1f) shows two different rings. the yellow rings correspond to different crystal planes of Ni5Mo, and the white rings correspond to different crystal planes of NiCo2O4. In addition, the distribution of Ni, Mo, Co and O in the heterostructure is shown by EDS line scanning and elemental mapping. As shown in Fig. 1(h) and (i), Ni and Mo mainly exists in the outer region and Co and O mainly distribute in the middle region, which indicates that the outer nanoparticles are mainly Ni5Mo and the inner nanoparticles are mainly NiCo2O4. This proves the combination of Ni5Mo and NiCo2O4, and Ni5Mo nanoparticles are deposited on the surface of NiCo2O4 nanoparticles. All the above analyses undoubtedly show that Ni5Mo/NiCo2O4 composites are successfully synthesized, and there are a lot of heterogeneous interfaces between Ni5Mo and NiCo2O4. 3.2 Valence state and electron transfer analysis In order to explore the effect of the combination of Ni5Mo and NiCo2O4 on the electronic structures of Ni, Mo and Co, the chemical states of Ni5Mo/NF, NiCo2O4/NF and Ni5Mo/NiCo2O4/NF were characterized by XPS. All characteristic peaks of Ni, Mo, Co and O elements are shown in the corresponding XPS spectra (Fig. S5a). As seen in Ni 2p and Mo 3d XPS spectra (Fig. 2 a and 2b), for the Ni5Mo/NiCo2O4/NF catalyst, an obvious shift (0.31 and 0.35 eV respectively) of Ni0 and Mo0 XPS peaks toward lower binding energy compared to those for Ni5Mo/NF was observed, implying that the Ni0 and Mo0 get electrons from NiCo2O4 and the electron density of Ni0 and Mo0 increases [44,45]. The characteristic XPS peaks of Ni2+, Mo4+ and Mo6+ for Ni5Mo/NF could be attributed to oxidized species formed on the surface of sample due to inevitable contact with air. On the other hand, the fixed XPS peak positions of Ni2+, Ni3+ and Ni(Co)-O imply that there are no chemical bonds forming between Ni0/Mo0 and Ni ions/O, as shown in Fig. 2(a), (d). On the contrary, in the high resolution Co 2p scan (Fig. 2c and S5c), Co 2p3/2 and Co 2p1/2 peaks for Ni5Mo/NiCo2O4/NF both shift to lower binding energy compared to NiCo2O4/NF, corresponding to higher oxidation states for the Co ions in Ni5Mo/NiCo2O4/NF according to literatures [46,47], indicating strong chemical bond is formed between Co2+/Co3+ and Ni0/Mo0, leading to electron transfer from Co2+ and Co3+ in NiCo2O4 to Ni0 and Mo0 in Ni5Mo [47]. The schematic diagram of electron transfer of Ni5Mo/NiCo2O4/NF is shown in Fig. 2(e). The above XPS analysis suggest that the combination of Ni5Mo and NiCo2O4 would change the chemical environment of Ni0, Mo0 and Co ions, resulting in strong electron interactions and promoting electron transfer from Co2+ and Co3+ to Ni0 and Mo0, which means that the electron density of Ni0 and Mo0 sites increases and the electron density of Co2+ and Co3+ sites decreases. According to previous studies, the increase of electron density of Ni0 and Mo0 active sites will lead to the weaker hydrogen adsorption on Ni0 and Mo0, which is conducive to improving the HER activity [48–50]. On the other hand, it is considered that Co3+ located at the octahedral position in NiCo2O4 is the catalytic active site of OER [51–53]. The reduced electron density of this site shows higher electron acceptance characteristics, thus would optimize the adsorption of OH− and promote the formation of OOH, in addition, the decrease of electron density of Co3+ would also promotes the deprotonation of OOH, which is conducive to the formation of O2 molecules, improving the electrocatalytic OER activity [54–56]. The enhanced bifunctional catalytic activity of Ni5Mo/NiCo2O4/NF for HER/OER will be discussed in the electrochemical test section. 3.3 HER catalytic activity The HER activities of the as-prepared samples were evaluated in 1 M KOH electrolyte purged with N2. Fig. 3 (a) shows the iR-corrected LSV curves of different catalysts for HER. Specifically, the overpotential of Ni5Mo/NiCo2O4/NF (44 mV) at 10 mA cm−2 is comparable to that of commercial Pt/C/NF (31 mV), which is much lower than those of Ni5Mo/NF (112 mV), NiCo2O4/NF (229 mV) and Ni5Mo+NiCo2O4/NF (102 mV), respectively. Compared with the physically mixed sample (Ni5Mo+NiCo2O4/NF), the overpotential of Ni5Mo/NiCo2O4/NF is much lower, indicating that the combination of Ni5Mo and NiCo2O4 produces a synergistic catalytic effect, which further significantly reduces the overpotential. The HER overpotential of Ni5Mo/NiCo2O4/NF at 500 mA cm−2 is only 229 mV, even lower than that of commercial Pt/C/NF (280 mV). On the other hand, Ni5Mo/NiCo2O4/NF shows the lowest Tafel slope of 60.9 mV dec−1 compared to isolated Ni5Mo/NF, NiCo2O4/NF and physically mixed Ni5Mo+NiCo2O4/NF catalysts (Fig. 3c), indicating that the combination of Ni5Mo and NiCo2O4 is conducive to improving HER kinetics, which is further supported by the EIS results [57,58]. As shown in Fig. 3(d) and table S2, Ni5Mo/NiCo2O4/NF has the smallest interface electron transfer resistance (R ct=6.74 Ω), especially much smaller than Ni5Mo+NiCo2O4/NF (R ct=33.19 Ω), which affords much faster electron transfer attributed to the synergistic effect of Ni5Mo and NiCo2O4, and in turn, promoting the HER process. The detailed electrochemical data are summarized in Table S2. In addition, the electrochemically active surface area (ECSA) analysis (Fig. S7) is estimated by the double-layer capacitance (Cdl) in a non-Faradaic potential range (0.20 to 0.25 V vs. RHE) at different scanning rates (Fig. S6). This analysis is a measurement method of the density of exposed active sites [59]. It is worth noting that Ni5Mo/NiCo2O4/NF has the largest electrochemical surface area, which proves that the combination of Ni5Mo and NiCo2O4 can increase the number of active sites. The intrinsic HER activity is also investigated by normalizing the kinetic current density at an overpotential of 100 mV with respect to ECSA. As shown in Fig. 3(e), Ni5Mo/NiCo2O4/NF exhibits significantly enhanced HER specific activity compared to other catalysts, which is about 4.8-fold as large as those of Ni5Mo/NF, about 4.5-fold as large as those of Ni5Mo+NiCo2O4/NF and even far surpassing NiCo2O4/NF. Compared to Ni5Mo+NiCo2O4/NF, the HER activity of Ni5Mo/NiCo2O4/NF is significantly improved, indicating that the combination of Ni5Mo and NiCo2O4 has a synergistic catalytic effect, which greatly improves the inherent HER activity of the catalyst. Overall, benefiting from the combination of Ni5Mo and NiCo2O4 and the synergistic catalytic effect between them, the effective active surface area and intrinsic activity of Ni5Mo/NiCo2O4/NF have been significantly improved, and finally excellent HER catalytic performance was obtained. In addition to superior HER activity, the Ni5Mo/NiCo2O4/NF catalyst also shows excellent long-term HER stability. Fig. 3(f) shows that after 50 h stability test, the overpotential of Ni5Mo/NiCo2O4/NF does not increase significantly, which further proves its excellent stability during HER process. The LSV curve of Ni5Mo/NiCo2O4/NF recorded after 50 h testing shows negligible degradation as compared to that originally obtained (inset of Fig. 3f). 3.4 OER catalytic activity Next, we further studied the OER catalytic activities of the prepared catalysts in oxygen saturated 1 M KOH. The polarization curves of NiCo2O4/NF and Ni5Mo/NiCo2O4/NF in Fig. 4 (a) show the presence of an oxidation peak around 1.33 V vs. RHE, which can be attributed to the oxidation of Ni2+ to Ni3+ and Co2+ to Co3+ or Co4+ [60–62]. As shown in Fig. 4(a) and 4(b), the overpotential of Ni5Mo/NiCo2O4/NF (305 mV) at 50 mA cm−2 is much lower than those of NiCo2O4/NF (332 mV), Ni5Mo/NF (434 mV), Ni5Mo+NiCo2O4/NF (386 mV) and RuO2/NF (345 mV), respectively. Specially, the overpotential of Ni5Mo/NiCo2O4/NF is lower than that of Ni5Mo+NiCo2O4/NF, indicating that the synergistic catalytic effect between Ni5Mo and NiCo2O4 can further improve the catalytic activity of OER. Morever, compared to other catalysts, Ni5Mo/NiCo2O4/NF has the lowest Tafel slope and the smallest interfacial electron transfer resistance (R ct=5.26 Ω), indicating that the combination of Ni5Mo and NiCo2O4 is conducive to improve OER kinetics and afford much faster electron transfer (Fig. 4c,d and Table S3). Besides, the ECSA analysis (Fig. S10) is estimated by the double-layer capacitance (Cdl) in a non-Faradaic potential range (0.83 V to 0.88 V vs. RHE) at different scanning rates (Fig. S9). As shown in Fig. S9, the ECSA of Ni5Mo/NiCo2O4/NF is smaller than that of NiCo2O4/NF. Therefore, we speculate that the OER performance improvement of Ni5Mo/NiCo2O4/NF is not due to the increase in the number of active sites compared to NiCo2O4/NF. Next, Fig. 4(e) shows the intrinsic OER activity studied by normalizing the kinetic current density of ECSA at an overpotential of 100 mV. The highest specific activity of Ni5Mo/NiCo2O4/NF further proves that the combination of Ni5Mo and NiCo2O4 produces a synergistic catalytic effect, which greatly improves the inherent OER activity of the catalyst. These results certify that the synergistic catalytic effect between Ni5Mo and NiCo2O4 enable superior kinetics and intrinsic activity in Ni5Mo/NiCo2O4/NF, resulting in excellent OER catalytic performance. As shown in Fig. 4(f), after 50 h stability test, the overpotential of Ni5Mo/NiCo2O4/NF does not increase significantly, the LSV curve of Ni5Mo/NiCo2O4/NF recorded after 50 h testing shows negligible degradation as compared to that originally obtained (inset of Fig. 4f), indicating its excellent stability during OER process. To further explore the structure variation of Ni5Mo/NiCo2O4/NF during the catalytic reaction, SEM and XRD tests were performed on the Ni5Mo/NiCo2O4/NF catalyst after 50 h HER and OER stability test. As shown in Fig. S12 and S13, the morphology and phase of the sample have not changed after the stability test, indicating that the electrode has outstanding structural stability. Furthermore, XPS spectra were also employed to study the structure of Ni5Mo/NiCo2O4/NF electrode after the stability test. (Fig. S14). After HER stability test, the peaks of Ni 2p, Mo 3d and Co 2p did not shift, proving that Ni5Mo/NiCo2O4/NF has excellent chemical stability during HER process. The reduction of Ni° content can be attributed to the inevitable oxidation of the sample during the test. After OER stability test, only Ni3+, Mo6+, Co3+ species for Ni 2p, Mo 3d, Co 2p XPS spectrum can be detected due to the high oxidation environment. 3.5 Overall water splitting performance As illustrated in Table S4, the HER and OER catalytic activities of Ni5Mo/NiCo2O4/NF are competitive to the state-of-the-art non-noble metal-based bifunctional electrocatalysts recently reported in literatures. Considering the enhanced HER and OER performance, we employed the Ni5Mo/NiCo2O4/NF as a bifunctional catalyst to further explore its potential application for overall water splitting. To deliver a current density of 10 mA cm−2, the Ni5Mo/NiCo2O4/NF||Ni5Mo/NiCo2O4/NF couple electrolyzer requires a cell voltage as low as 1.54 V (Fig. 5 a), which is much lower than Ni5Mo/NF||NiCo2O4/NF (1.61 V). At the same time, it needs only 1.74 V and 1.99 V to deliver high current densities of 100 mA cm−2 and 400 mA cm−2, respectively, even lower than the noble metal-based catalyst (Pt/C/NF||RuO2/NF). Such performance is superior to most of the transition-metal-based efficient bifunctional catalysts recently reported (Table S4). In addition, as shown in Fig. 5(b), we tested the stability of Ni5Mo/NiCo2O4/NF||Ni5Mo/NiCo2O4/NF at a current density of 100 mA cm−2 for 50 h, the overpotential exhibits no obvious attenuation, and the stability was significantly better than that of Pt/C/NF||RuO2/NF. 4 Conclusions In conclusion, we successfully prepared NiMo/NiCo2O4 heterojunction on foam nickel by hydrothermal-annealing-electrodeposition. Because of the strong electronic interaction between Ni5Mo and NiCo2O4, the catalyst exhibits excellent HER and OER catalytic activity. For HER, the Ni5Mo/NiCo2O4/NF hybrid catalyst displays a low overpotential of only 44 mV at 10 mA cm−2, and 229 mV at 500 mA cm−2. For OER, it needs an overpotential as low as 305 mV to reach 50 mA cm−2. When the catalyst is used as both cathode and anode for overall water splitting, the whole electrochemical water decomposition can be carried out at a stable current density of 10 mA cm−2 with a low cell voltage of 1.54 V, and could reach a high electrolysis current density of 400 mA cm−2 at only 1.99 V. In addition, the catalyst has excellent long-term stability. Therefore, Ni5Mo/NiCo2O4/NF, as a low-cost catalyst, is expected to be a substitute for precious metal based catalysts in industrial water electrolysis. coredata.dc:description: It is highly desirable to develop efficient and low-cost bifunctional HER/OER electrocatalysts for overall water splitting. Herein, Ni5Mo/NiCo2O4 heterojunctions loaded on nickel foam were prepared. The catalyst shows excellent bifunctional activity, with an HER overpotential of 44 mV at 10 mA cm−2 and an OER overpotential of 305 mV at 50 mA cm−2 in alkaline electrolyte. In addition, it is worth noting that the overpotential of HER and OER at 500 mA cm−2 are only 229 mV and 368 mV, respectively. It is evidenced that the combination of Ni5Mo and NiCo2O4 transfers electrons from Co2+/Co3+ to Ni0/Mo0, which optimizes the electronic structures of the active sites of Ni0, Mo0 and Co3+, thus greatly enhances the intrinsic HER and OER activities. When Ni5Mo/NiCo2O4/NF is used as anode and cathode for water splitting under alkaline conditions, a stable current density of 10 mA cm−2 can be achieved at a low cell voltage of 1.54 V and a long-term stability up to 50 h. This work highlights the synergy effect of alloy and oxide heterojunctions in efficient water electrocatalysis.
coredata.dc:title: NiMo/NiCo2O4 as synergy catalyst supported on nickel foam for efficient overall water splitting
